content.description: Left of shamu, obvious roof. Start on left-most jug and traverse right and top out. Slightly harder variation--dont start with the feet on the block at the bottom.
content.location: Left of Shamu on the roof lip.

content.description: Technical, tall and terrific! Start on thin crimps and find your way up steep slab to finger crack then top out high above.
content.protection: Bouldering Pads: Bring a few pads and a good spotter. There is a small tree growing near the base which could be and ankle bender on a bad fall.
content.location: Top of the Shamoo area. Face just left of the blunt Shamoo (V6) arête.

content.description:
Heaven climbs the striking seam on the Shamoo boulder.  A longtime project due to its location and just beg to be climbed line. 

  Begin by pulling onto the wall with a miserable opening in the hairline seam with your left hand and right on a tiny (1/4") crimp).  Cam the right foot into the bottom, wide part of the crack.  Lean left and reach high to hook your right middle finger into the mono.  This hold is not so much of a mono as a tooth for one finger.  Left foot on the most miserable foothold imaginable.  Stand onto it and reach high left hand to where the crack offsets.  Begin strenuous, delicate laybacking to the topout.   

  The mono is notorious for injuring fingers, and I worry that if my left foot would skate off the smeary edge, one could lose the finger.  Do not let this scare you away from the problem.  The tweakiness can be mitigated by listening to your body.  I have seen this climb flashed.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spotter.

content.description:
Shamoo is one of the top ten boulder problems of Mt Gretna.  It embodies all of what diabase climbing is about: small holds, balance and most importantly technique.  Shamoo climbs the striking seam and left arete on the most prominent boulder in the area.  

  Begin easily enough by laybacking up the left arete whilst smearing.  Work your way into a position where you will be spanning between the arete and crack with your hands and no feet.   

  Hike the left foot up to nearly nothing, perch for all you are worth and reach up high left to a tiny, nearly unusable sidepull.  Stomp the right smear up, no up further.  Then fire out right for the opening in the crack.  Hug the features for another move, then topout easily.
content.location: Large boulder with the striking seam Heaven (V8) and a blunt left arete.  Cant miss it.

content.description:
Climb the dihedral to the left of Shamoo, on the same boulder.  Start standing and lieback or stem up the slippery dihedral using a thin crack for the hands to a tall and delicate sloping lip encounter that is guaranteed to raise the heart rate.     

  Often overlooked due to the popularity of the adjacent Shamoo arete.  I highly recommend this problem if you are looking for a scare similar to that of Shamoo.  With good technique, this climb can be performed without much difficulty.
content.protection: More than one pad would be best along with a spotter.
content.location: The dihedral to the left of the Shamoo arete and Heaven crack.
Top of the Shamoo area. Large, blocky arete 10 feet of Heaven crack (V8).

content.description: Large boulder with the striking seam Heaven (V8) and a blunt left arete.
